BE11:10am

Five pars from UBS's Keith Parker et al.

Mouselet ( that's the same way that I think of some of the steel-industry stuff )
11:10 am
BE11:10am

With the tax cut passed and Gary Cohn resigning, the trade pendulum is swinging and raising uncertainty. Starting with solar panels and washing machines, followed by the announcement of broad tariffs on steel and aluminum, investors are assessing the prospect for retaliation and actions against China as NAFTA negotiations continue. While trade uncertainty is rising, we would remind investors that the impacts of steel/aluminum tariffs (~$10bn cost) pale in comparison to the Border Adjustment Tax (BAT) of 20% on all imports (~$600bn cost) that was pushed by the GOP early last year. An escalation of trade frictions is not in our baseline, and thus is a risk to our positive view, with protectionism a headwind for productivity growth and S&P margins.

BE11:10am

A 25% tariff on steel imports of ~$29bn would be a cost of $7.3bn while a 10% tariff on aluminum imports of ~$23bn would be $2.3bn. That is less than 0.7% of S&P profits, as costs would likely be passed through. With a US GDP growth impact of less than 10bps (link), the sales impact would be small. For 71 industries, we estimate the direct impact based on the respective import tariff and the indirect impact based on industry usage of primary/fabricated metals which use imported steel/aluminum. Electrical equip/appliances and machinery are most affected (~0.35% of output), followed by autos/parts, furniture and other transportation equipment. Our industry analysts assess stock level impacts for autos, industrials, and powersports companies.

BE11:11am

(It's taking all my strength of will not to correct the spelling of "aluminium" in that.)

11:11 am
BE11:11am

With the IP investigation, we see rising risks of trade actions against China. Given inherent difficulties of a tariff on IP, tariffs could be placed on select China imports, which total $500bn. Thus, headline risk could be notable, but implementation of any tariff would be challenging making a broad impact less likely. Across industries, imports from China are greatest for cell phones, tech hardware, apparel, semis and various consumer goods. For NAFTA and thus Canada and Mexico, we see actions before Mexican elections in July and US midterm elections in November as unlikely, and a prolonged period of negotiation that is unlikely to lead to dramatic changes.

BE11:11am

Two more pars.

BE11:11am

Trade enables productivity, with NBER estimates of ~20% of productivity growth due to trade in the last cycle (link). An escalation to a trade war would weigh on trade and reduce future growth expectations. Based on our model, the S&P 500 P/E is very sensitive to 3-5yr expected EPS growth with a beta of 2.38x. In a downside scenario, productivity that is 20% lower because of weakening trade would be a 25-35bp hit to growth, and a 0.6-0.8x hit to the P/E. The S&P 500 P/E fell by 0.7x from Feb 26 to Mar 1 as trade issues came to the fore, suggesting quite a lot was priced. With the S&P 500 forward P/E 1.5x below Jan levels, and still 0.4x below Feb 26 levels, we see risks of higher rates and increased protectionism as priced, but better potential growth is not.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

We view the public reactions of Cohn, select Republicans, corporates and sovereigns together with the equity selloff as acting as headwinds to protectionist momentum, particularly with midterm elections nine months away. We also see the tax plan "carrot" of $280bn in stimulus, with 1/3 to S&P 500 firms, as much bigger than the "stick" of protectionist actions and rhetoric. Across industries, electrical equipment, furniture and autos/comp are down 4-6% since Feb 15 suggesting there may be select buying opportunities.

Mouselet What is the equivalent of selling ammunition to both sides in a trade-war context?
Mouselet If the US and China are going to do damaging things to one another, at least I would like it to have a positive effect on my retirement fund

BE11:20am

In short: Good FCF performance in 2017, Power Systems particularly strong.

2018 FCF guide is in line to slightly ahead of consensus expectations. TrentXWB program is on track and cash losses fell 37% in 2017. The run-rate costs savings target of £200mn has been achieved, earlier than expected. Trent 1000 and Trent900 technical issues cost £170mn in 2017, this is expected to double in 2018 and then fall; this is covered in guidance. IFRS 15 adjustment is slightly higher than expected at profit but this is due to better Trent700 pricing. 2017 FCF: £273mn vs. company compiled consensus £129mn
2018 FCF Guide: £350mn - £550mn (vs. company compiled consensus £405mn), 11% ahead of consensus at the mid-point.
Cost Savings: Current plan has achieved £200mn run-rate savings, at the top end of the plan, and this has been done by the end of 2017 vs 2018 anticipated. IFRS 15 adjustment: Slightly higher than expected (£854mn vs. guide for less than £823mn) due to better Trent 700 pricing.
Trent XWB: Cash losses down 37% in 2017. Expect similar level of losses in 2018. ITP: Excluded from company guidance, expecting a €70-80mn outflow in 2018.

FY 2017 results in a nutshell: FY 2017 revenues beat BBG consensus by 2%. FY 2017 RR defined EBITA beat BBG consensus by 21%. However, RR capitalised £342m of R&D, up from £99m in 2016 and we are sure this was not expected by the market; adjusting for this we would say 2017 earnings were broadly in line. FY 2017 FCF beat J.P. Morgan estimates by £126m; this should be well received by the market although the guidance from RR had set a very low bar.

Coming into today we were excited that IFRS 15
would “lift the accounting fog” that has made RR so hard to analyse historically. We had not expected a huge increase in capitalised R&D, so it feels a little like two steps forward and one step back. Given FCF guidance is in line investors may not be too bothered but the fact remains that RR’s guidance for 2018 EBITA in Civil Aero (under IFRS 15) is now c£-220m, after benefitting from capitalised R&D. Assuming all the capitalised R&D is in Civil Aero, the division’s clean EBITA (ie. after deducting capitalised R&D) could be a loss over £-500m, much weaker than we expected.

Following share price outperformance there is limited upside to our 12-month price target and as a result we downgrade Smurfit Kappa to Neutral (from Buy). We believe the stock outperformed on: 1) margin expansion, and 2) the announcement of a potential bid from International Paper. Since adding to the Buy List on September 11, 2017, Smurfit shares are up 32.2% (SKG.I) and 30.5% (SKG.L) vs our paper and packaging coverage up 12% on average and vs. FTSE World Europe down 2.2% (in EUR terms) and down 4% (in £ terms).

BE12:00pm

RTN's results were unsurprisingly in line with our forecasts following the January trading statement. Current trading is 'broadly in line' (code for a little below) with expectations with the brief but savage cold weather snap clearly unhelpful for trading. It's a relatively quiet time of year and there is enough momentum in the business to persuade us to leave our forecasts unchanged. The balance sheet is in good shape and the dividend was maintained as a sign of confidence in the future. RTN is a recovery play, in our view, but it's going to take longer as the market continues to soften. We believe the dismal share price performance (-22% YTD) gives a real buying opportunity for patient investors, and the 6.6% dividend yield should ease the wait until recovery is served.

Blank canvas thanks for Smurfit and AA coverage.

The group is pointing in the right direction but the point of departure (over-exposure on retail parks, high prices & margins etc.) is a drag.

Execution remains key. Fore our thoughts thereon, please get in touch.

As we mentioned earlier, a glance at RTN’s PER, dividend yield etc. suggest that its shares are prima facie cheap but there remains much to be done.
